author: cbc
title: B.C. residents now have up to $12 K incentive to trade in a gas guzzler for zero-emission vehicle
text:
B.C. residents can now save up to $12,000 dollars if they choose to trade in an old car for a zero-emission vehicle.
B.C.'s Minister of Energy Bill Bennett announced the measure Friday, along with a separate investment of $40 million to encourage B.C. residents to make the switch.
The province's Clean Energy Vehicles for B.C. program will offer up to $5,000 for an electric vehicle purchase and $6,000 for a hydrogen fuel cell vehicle.
A non-profit society called B.C. Scrap-It currently offers $6,000 dollars towards electric vehicles purchases, bringing the total savings up to $12,000.
Vehicles priced above $77,000 remain ineligible for purchase incentives.
Growing the EV market Other programs funded within the $40 million include expanding public and residential charging infrastructure, supporting job training in the zero-emission vehicle sector, and increasing public awareness of the benefits of electric vehicles.
"Transportation accounts for nearly half of the emissions by the average B.C. family, and light-duty vehicles account for 14% of B.C.'s overall emissions," Minister of Environment Mary Polak said in a release.
"With 98% of our electricity in B.C coming from clean or renewable sources, encouraging people to buy or lease a zero-emission vehicle is one of best ways we can reduce greenhouse gas emissions and ensure British Columbia remains a climate action leader."
According to the province, B.C has the highest ratio of zero-emission vehicle sales and the largest charging network in Canada.
A report released by SFU's Sustainable Transportation Action Research Team in November gave B.C.'s electric vehicle program a C-minus, and called on the federal government and provinces to introduce supply-focused policies.
